frame.name: Cause_to_perceive
frame.definition:
<def-root>An <fen>Agent</fen>, <fen>Actor</fen>, <fen>Entity</fen>, or <fen>Medium</fen> causes a <fen>Phenomenon</fen> to be perceived by a <fen>Perceiver</fen>. With an <fen>Actor</fen>, <fen>Entity</fen>, or <fen>Medium</fen>, the <fen>Perceiver</fen> is usually unspecified.
<ex><fex name="Agent">Aileen</fex> <t>showed</t> <fex name="Perceiver">Rob</fex> <fex name="Phenomenon">the book</fex>.</ex> <ex><fex name="Actor">He</fex> <t>exhibited</t> <fex name="Phenomenon">great interest in the project</fex>.</ex> <ex><fex name="Medium">The second scene</fex> <t>depicts</t> <fex name="Phenomenon"> Dad </fex> <fex name="Phenomenon">holding the ball for a place kick</fex>.</ex> <ex><fex name="Entity">The economy</fex> is <t>showing</t> <fex name="Phenomenon">signs of growth</fex>.</ex>
NB: This may change in the future, but as of now this frame subsumes three closely-related cause/perceiver alternations: a.) perception of a specific <fen>Perceiver</fen> caused by an <fen>Agent</fen>, b.) perception of some implicit audience caused, possibly unintentionally, by an <fen>Actor</fen>, and c.) perception of some implicit audience caused by a <fen>Medium</fen> or <fen>Entity</fen>. Perhaps this frame is too broad - the different subject FEs seem to all indicate different ways of "showing."</def-root>

FE.name: Agent
FE.definition: <def-root>The <fen>Agent</fen> intentionally creates a situation in which the <fen>Perceiver</fen> observes or experiences the <fen>Phenomenon</fen>.</def-root>

FE.name: Phenomenon
FE.definition: <def-root>The <fen>Phenomenon</fen> is an entity or idea that is perceived by the <fen>Perceiver</fen>.</def-root>

FE.name: Perceiver
FE.definition: <def-root>The <fen>Perceiver</fen> is made to have a perceptual experience by the <fen>Agent</fen>.</def-root>

FE.name: Means
FE.definition: <def-root>The instrument or method by which the <fen>Perceiver</fen> was shown the <fen>Phenomenon</fen>.</def-root>

FE.name: Manner
FE.definition: <def-root>A description of the way in which the <fen>Agent</fen> presents the <fen>Phenomenon</fen>.</def-root>

FE.name: Frequency
FE.definition: <def-root><fen>Frequency</fen> describes how often the <fen>Agent</fen> presents the <fen>Phenomenon</fen>.</def-root>

FE.name: Place
FE.definition: <def-root>The location where the <fen>Agent</fen> causes the perception of the <fen>Perceiver</fen>.</def-root>

FE.name: Purpose
FE.definition: <def-root>The purpose of the <fen>Agent</fen> in creating the perception of the <fen>Perceiver</fen>.</def-root>

FE.name: Actor
FE.definition: <def-root>An <fen>Actor</fen> is a sentient being who is exhibiting, possibly uninintentionally, some <fen>Phenomenon</fen>.</def-root>

FE.name: Entity
FE.definition: <def-root>An object that has some association with a <fen>Phenomenon</fen>.</def-root>

FE.name: Co-participant
FE.definition: <def-root>A <fex name="Co-participant">Co-participant</fex> is an entity that participates in a coordinated way in the same event as the <fen>Actor</fen> or <fen>Co-participant</fen> Agent.</def-root>

FE.name: Explanation
FE.definition: <def-root>The Explanation denotes a proposition from which the main clause (headed by the target) logically follows.</def-root>

lexUnit.name: show.v
lexUnit.definition: FN: to make visible or noticeable

lexUnit.name: demonstrate.v
lexUnit.definition: FN: to give an explanation and/or exhibition of

lexUnit.name: present.v
lexUnit.definition: FN: to exhibit something to others

lexUnit.name: point.v
lexUnit.definition: FN: to indicate the existense or direction of something or some event

lexUnit.name: depict.v
lexUnit.definition: COD: represent by a drawing, painting, or other art form

lexUnit.name: represent.v
lexUnit.definition: WN: express indirectly by an image, form, or model

lexUnit.name: present[medical].v
lexUnit.definition: FN: symptomatic characteristics exhibited by a patient

lexUnit.name: bring to attention.v
lexUnit.definition: FN: To cause a perciever to pay attention to the phenomenon
